comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/51979177@N02] Ha ha thanks! Yes, this photo shows the 1887 extension work to the Customs House (James Barnet, architect, modifying the original two-storey building by Mortimer Lewis). See - [http://www.flickr.com/photos/27331537@N06/5474994472/] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/angeljim46] They extended again twelve or so years later!

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
About the EMU (1865 - this ISN'T the 1841 ship) -
"The Manly paddler 'Brightside' (269 tons - 950 passengers) was built in Glasgow and exported to Brisbane to be reassembled for use on the Brisbane River and Moreton Bay as PS EMU. She was originally owned by the Queensland Steam Navigation Company. After another owner, she came to the Port Jackson Steam Boat Company in January 1877 and stayed with the various forms of the Manly ferry company until 1909. She was renamed BRIGHTSIDE in 1887 and sank in June 1897. She was converted into a cargo ferry in 1902 and worked the Manly run in that role until 1908. After being gutted by fire in 1908 the hull was converted to a lighter, but was broken up in 1909."
From "A Pictorial History of Ferries, Sydney and surrounding waterways" Graeme Andrews, Reed 1982

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: During its Brisbane years, the Emu appears to have spent a good deal of its time plying between Brisbane and Ipswich...and also carrying excursionists on trips up and down the Brisbane River and to Moreton Bay, albeit with the occasional mishap. nla.gov.au/nla.news-article1280580 - 1865 Brisbane Courier report on the Emu's initial trial ; nla.gov.au/nla.news-article1281206 report on the first trial run to Moreton Bay Advertised for sale in early December 1876 - column 2 (above 'Religious Announcements') nla.gov.au/nla.news-article1393639 Per the shipping intelligence, the Emu departed Brisbane to start a new life in Sydney (a familiar Queensland story!) on 23 December, 1876...towed by the ASN Company's steamer the Egmont...arrived in Sydney on 30 December, 1876...

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: In 1887 the EMU also had a collision with the WARATAH which sank just to the left of this photo. Maybe just after this photo was taken?! - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/13627954

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/51979177@N02] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/angeljim46] I can see you are all well-versed on the history of the Customs House extensions :) EMU had an interesting time, this Sydney Mail article says P&O liner CARTHAGO was in Circular Quay at the time of the collision, shame we can't see further along the east side in this pic.
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: Mort & Co's wool stores...the 'original' building was completed in 1870 - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article70461600 ; nla.gov.au/nla.news-page5453431 ; the additions were completed in 1886 - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article13635130 ; Goldsborough and Mort amalgamated in 1888...after which the building became known as the Goldsborough Mort & Co wool store...later it became the Farmers & Graziers Building...here's an 1895 T&CJ item nla.gov.au/nla.news-article71220755 ; also see pics 112 and 113 in this Mort family album held at SLNSW acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/album/albumView.aspx?acmsID=430589&amp... ...pic 112 in this album has been dated to the micro-second by You-Know-Who (!) www.flickr.com/photos/24785917@N03/2495797591/in/photolis... (see thumbnail below)

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/51979177@N02] That's great information - I meant to work out the dates of the Mort warehouse yonks ago, but never got round to it.  The first time I saw it in old photos I thought "yuk, what an ugly building, thank goodness that went!"  But it steadily grew on me, and evidently a lot of 19th-century folk (including Arthur Streeton) who remarked that Circular Quay in the 1890s resembled Venice, particularly due to the architecture of the Mort warehouse, the tower and domes of the Lands Department Building, the 1893 Goldsborough warehouse tower. etc.

One thing I am not sure about - the 1870 original bit is the front left (next to Phillip Street) two-fifths of the north front without the upper floors (see illustration in your first link).  Was the right hand three-fifths (duplicate plus one-way alley in between) added at the same time as the upper two floors (completed 1886)?  I think so, as I don't remember seeing any photos of a broad, lower building.

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] You're right...ie. all of what we see of the Mort & Co building in this ANMM pic dates from 1886 (or whenever the extension commenced)...the original 1870 part of the building isn't quite visible...I'll adjust my note accordingly... We get a good idea of the extent of the 1886 extension from these before and after pics: Before - acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemLarge.aspx?itemID=414336 I'd say the T&CJ artist was using this pic attributed to Charles Pickering After - nla.gov.au/nla.pic-vn5779292
